titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Richard P. Wunder Research Files, 1945-1989MS.02
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Finding aid prepared by Shannon Yule.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit2013-12-16T14:14-0500

repository.corpname: The Frick Collection/Frick Art Reference Library Archives

physdesc.extent: (74 boxes, 7 note card boxes, oversize material)

did.abstract: Research files of art historian Richard P. Wunder, containing artwork files, photographs, correspondence, writings and notes. Content mostly consists of his research on Gian Paolo Panini, though Hyacinthe Rigaud, Emmanuel Leutze, and architectural and theatre drawings are prominent topics as well.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection consists mainly of Richard P. Wunder's research files on 18th century Italian painter and architect, Gian Paolo Panini, and George Van Derveer Gallenkamp's research files on French Baroque painter, Hyacinthe Rigaud. Wunder received the Rigaud material as a bequest from Gallenkamp. Materials on German-American history painter, Emmanuel Leutze, and architectural and theater drawings also figure prominently. These research topics stemmed from Wunder's personal scholarly interests and his career interests as a curator and director. Materials include correspondence, photographs, drafts, publications, and notes that relate to the creation of exhibits, lectures, catalogs, articles, and theses.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Arranged and described by Diane Krieger, 1997; Shannon Yule, 2009.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Gift of Dr. Richard P. Wunder.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: These records are open for research under the conditions of The Frick Collection/Frick Art Reference Library Archives access policy. Contact the Archives Department for further information at archives@frick.org.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Richard P. Wunder, art historian, was born in Ardmore, Pennsylvania. He developed an interest in art while traveling with his mother in Europe. Wunder pursued this interest at Harvard, earning his bachelors, masters, and doctorate degrees in fine art. Between his studies, Wunder served in the army during WWII and the Korean War. After receiving his doctorate, Wunder became the Curator of Drawings and Prints at Cooper Union Museum, serving in this position from 1955-1964. He then went on to become the Curator of Painting and Sculpture for the National Collection of Fine Arts, Smithsonian from 1964-1968. Wunder returned to New York City as the Director for the Cooper-Hewitt Museum of Design from 1968-1970. During the 1970s, he taught at Middlebury College. He later became president of appraisals for Christie, Manson & Woods before retiring in 1990 to La Jolla, California. Richard Wunder died in 2002, at the age of 79.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in eight series. Each series represents a research subject area.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Richard P. Wunder Research Files. The Frick Collection/Frick Art Reference Library Archives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Panini material forms the bulk of Richard Wunder's research files. Wunder began his study of Panini--16th century Italian painter and architect--during his undergraduate career at Harvard. He completed theses about Panini for his bachelor and doctorate degrees, and maintained a lifelong interest in his work. This series consists mainly of artwork files that contain photographs and provenance information. Additionally, Wunder's writings on the topic of Panini, including his theses; correspondence regarding Panini; printed works regarding Panini; and notes and other research material are included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The artwork files form the bulk of Wunder's research material on Panini. The files are subdivided into paintings, drawings, and engravings. Each folder contains a photograph of the artwork and a sheet listing the title, medium, size, owner, provenance, additional comments, and a photographer credit. Sometimes the folders include correspondence regarding attempts to obtain provenance information and/or photographs of the works.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The paintings are arranged alphabetically by city, then specific collection, and then title. This information was gathered at the time of Wunder's research and may not reflect current painting locations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Hyacinth Rigaud material was created and collected by a colleague of Wunder's, George Van Derveer Gallenkamp. Wunder received Gallenkamp's extensive research files regarding Rigaud as a bequest. The bulk of the material consists of artwork files containing photographs, provenance information, and correspondence. Also included are Gallenkamp's writings on the topic of Rigaud, including various articles, his thesis, and the beginnings of a catalogue raisonn├®. Additionally, the series contains correspondence, subject files, printed material, notes and other research material. Various Gallenkamp material not related to Rigaud is found at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Artwork files are arranged alphabetically by city. This arrangement reflects the location of Rigaud works at the time of Gallenkamp's research. Each folder contains material regarding one or more works by Rigaud located in that particular city. The files may contain photographs, correspondence, notes, or a combination.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Stored in MS Oversize Box B.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gallenkamp's writings on Rigaud include published articles with drafts, notes, photographs, and correspondence; the beginnings of a catalogue raisonn├®; and his thesis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Emmanuel Gottlieb Leutze was a German-American history painter best known for his paintingWashington Crossing the Delaware. This series contains materials regarding a Smithsonian exhibition of Leutze paintings and preparation of a biography and catalogue raisonn├®. Wunder was involved with these projects during his tenure as Curator of Painting and Sculpture for the National Collection of Fine Arts, Smithsonian. Included are artwork files, correspondence, notes and clippings, and various writings on Leutze.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Folders are arranged by subject, works are arranged alphabetically within each folder. Files consist mainly of provenance forms, although some works may include photocopied images, correspondence regarding provenance, other research materials, and rarely photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence with Raymond Stehle, a Leutze scholar, regarding publication of a biography and catalogue raisonn├®. Also includes correspondence with a variety of correspondents regarding a possible NCFA Leutze exhibit, and publication of the biography and catalogue raisonn├®, and various other requests for photographs etc. Also contains photocopies of Leutze correspondence from the 1850s held in the Smithsonian.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains newspaper clippings and notes regarding Leutze.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains writings about Leutze by Raymond Stehle, a published Leutze monograph by Barbara Groseclose, and various photocopied articles and catalogs whose publication dates range from 1865-1975.

did.unittitle: "Annotated List of the Works of Emanuel Leutze" by Raymond Stehle (photocopy)
Emmanuel Leutze, 1816-1868: Freedom is the Only Kingby Barbara S. Groseclose for the National Collection of Fine Arts (Smithsonian)
"The Life and Works of Emanuel Leutze" by Raymond Stehle (photocopy)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains Wunder's files for predominantly Italian artists from the 16th through 19th centuries. Contains photographs of artwork, and additionally some files may contain correspondence, printed material, biographical notes, or descriptions of works of art. Several folders do not contain any images of artwork.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence, photographs, published catalogs, drafts, notes, and promotional materials for five of Wunder's research projects that relate to architectural drawings (four in conjunction with an exhibition and catalog publication).

unittitle.emph: The Architect's Eye

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A 1962 Cooper Union exhibition of about 150 architectural drawings and prints selected from their collection. Wunder wrote the introduction to the catalog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes annotated published version and a galley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Richard Wunder was commissioned to write the catalog,Architectural and Ornament Drawings of the 16th to the Early 19th Centuries in the Collection of University of Michigan Museum of Art. The catalog describes and illustrates 107 drawings acquired by the Museum during the late 1950s and early 1960s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains photographs, correspondence, notes, and drafts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Materials relate to theSummary Catalogue of Drawings by Identified Italian Architects in the Cooper Union Museum, which Wunder wrote during his time there.

scopecontent.p: Relates to the exhibition and catalog,Architectural, Ornament, Landscape and Figure Drawings collected by Richard Wunder. Mr. Wunder's personal collection was exhibited at Middlebury College in 1975.
